In 2005, Elena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Subdra

texts.en:
Mrs. Subdra K. lives in Bhaishipati. Bhaishipati is located in Kathmandu district and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural work. Subdra K. is engaged in a goat raising business. She sells goats and goat milk in the local market. She already owns five goats and sells their goat milk in the local market. Now she is requesting a Rs 20,000.00 loan to buy baby goats for her business. She grows baby goats and sells in the local market.

Mrs. K. lives in a single family with her husband and two children. Her husband works in a private office. She is the mother of one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 12 and daughter is in grade 10.

loans.use: To buy baby goats

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is married with three children. He is 40 years old. His children are still dependent on him, and they are excelling in school. He sells crates of drinks at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. He has been in this business for a long time. He needs a loan of NGN 90,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: El Sol Group

texts.es:
La señora Maria C. integrante del grupo  El Sol que a su vez pertenece al Centro Focal Panamericana, indica que es parte de este grupo hace 4 años aproximadamente, ingreso un poco insegura, temerosa de que no pudiera cumplir con la deuda, pero como necesitaba dinero se arriesgó, ella vende dulces y helados en una cancha fabril y le va bien, ya que con esos ingresos ha podido sacar adelante sola a su familia, ya que ella es viuda, su hija también se encuentra en el grupo. Ahora necesita el préstamo para hacer reparar su máquina heladera. Las demás integrantes del grupo también tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de ropa, peluches, helados, masitas, costura de prendas de vestir, venta de tarjetas y atención de Internet.
Todas necesitan el préstamo, una vez más, para seguir invirtiendo en sus negocios y crecer día a día.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria C. is a member of the El Sol group which is itself a member of the Centro Focal Panamericana. She reports she has been a part of this group for approximately 4 years. When she joined she was a little uncertain and afraid that she wouldn't be able to pay off the debt, but since she needed money she took the risk. She sells candy and ice cream at a sports field and it's going well for her. With that income she has been able to get her family ahead by herself, since she is a widow. Her daughter is also in the group. Right now she needs the loan to be able to repair her ice cream machine. The other members of the group also have their own businesses such as the sale of clothes, stuffed animals, ice cream, baked goods, sewing clothing, and the sale of cards and internet service. They all need the loan, once again, to continue investing in their businesses and to grow day by day.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: THE PURCHASE OF MERCHANDISE AND TO REPAIR FIXED ASSETS

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca M. is from the village of Kauswagan, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. Francisca is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Francisca owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells both food & daily use products in the local community. Francisca has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Francisca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Francisca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Francisca opted to request a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Francisca from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to sell

loans.name: Olubukola

texts.en:
Olubukola is 31 years old, married and has a child. She is a hardworking woman who makes lovely Nigerian clothing styles for both male and female. She also sells tailoring accessories like zips, thread and landings and has been in this business or five years.

Olubukola hopes to become an international designer in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you and promises to repay her Kiva loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Olubumi

texts.en:
Olubumi sells medicine to make a living. She loves this business because of the profit. She hopes to grow her business. She has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization). LAPO, a Kiva partner, is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.  

Olubumi is 55 years old and married with three children. She is requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Karla Vanessa

texts.es:
La señora Karla C. es conserje en el instituto I N O de león en donde comienza sus labores a las 6am y la termina a las tres de la tarde de conserje. 

Este crédito que solicito es  para la compra de útiles escolares y pago de adelanto de colegiatura de su hijo 

Algo relevante de la señora Karla , es que  es madre soltera  y quiere sacar adelante a su hijo y además de de ser conserje también da servicios de lavado y planchado.
texts.en:
Sra. Karla C. is a janitor at the INO Institute in León. She starts working at 6am and ends at 3pm. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy school supplies and pay for her son’s tuition.

Something to know about Sra. Karla is that she is a single mother who wants to get ahead for her son. In addition to being a janitor, she also provides laundry and ironing services.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase school supplies & pay for her son's tuition

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling shoes and women's bags

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées, majoritairement dans des familles monogames, avec en moyenne 30 an, 3 enfants et habitant toutes à Bènèbougou, un village de la commune de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle d’entraide des femmes du village de Bènèbougou à l’occasion des travaux champêtres et des évènements sociaux (mariage, baptême, circoncision et funérailles). 
Le groupe Djiguissèmè qui est à son 4ème   prêt solidaire  avec Soro Yiriwaso, après avoir correctement remboursés, les trois précédents font entre autres, l’achat vente de céréales, leurs transformations, la  restauration et le commerce d’articles divers.  
Madame Fatoumata D., dans le souci de diversifier ses activités commerciales décida de faire l’étalagiste depuis maintenant 4 ans.  
Elle utilisera son montant pour acheter : 25 kg de sucre, 4 sachets de (10 petits paquets chacun) de différentes variétés de thés, 1 paquet de lipton, 6 paquets de bonbons, 2cartons de savon de lessive, 10 paquets de bleu et une dizaine de paquet de lames. 
Elle achète ses produits à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou et effectue ses ventes  à domicile au  comptant  et rarement à crédit à une clientèle mixte hommes, femmes et enfants.
Fatoumata espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 16500FCFA qui servira au remboursement de son prêt, à la contribution à certaines dépenses familiales et à la participation aux évènements (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles). 
Son ambition est de pérenniser son petit commerce afin d’être la 1ère femme  à ouvrir une boutique dans son village tout en préservant ses relations avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Djiguissèmè are all married, mostly in monogamous families, and average 30 years of age and three children each.  They all live in Bènèbougou, a village of the community of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, community, commercial activities, belonging to the same women's traditional mutual-assistance association of the village of Bènèbougou, during farm work efforts, and at societal events (marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals). The group members are on their fourth solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso after having correctly repaid all three previous ones.  Their work includes buying and selling grains and processing them, food catering, and commerce in a variety of goods. Ms. Fatoumata D., concerned about diversifying her commercial activities decided four year ago to working on displaying merchandise.  She will use the loan for buying:  25 kg of sugar, four pouches (10 small packets each) of tea of various kinds, a packet of Lipton, six packets of candy, two boxes of laundry soap, ten packets of bleu, and a dozen packets of razor blades.  She buys her supplies at the weekly Ségou fair and sells out of her home, cash accepted but rarely credit, from a customer base composed of men, women, and children. Fatoumata hopes to make a monthly profit of 16,500 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan, to help cover certain family expenses, and to take part in events (marriages, baptisms, and funerals).  Her ambition is to ensure that her small business continues in order to be the first woman to open a store in her village while preserving her association with Soro Yiriwaso.    

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various store goods

loans.name: Chou

texts.en: Chou S., 48, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She produces baskets for sale for an income of about USD 3.50 per day. Her husband is a social officer, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase more baskets for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy baskets for resale

loans.name: Nancy Maribel

texts.es:
Nancy Maribel C. Y.  tiene 19 años, es soltera, no tiene hijos  Viven en el recinto San Francisco de Rumí pamba a una hora y media del  Cantón San Miguel Provincia de Bolívar.
Ella es socia  miembro de la ventanilla rural “San Francisco de Rumí pamba”.  La misma que esta conformada por 25 socios en total, los cuales la mayoría se dedican a la agricultura.
Nancy trabaja en la agricultura toda su vida, como  fuente económica principal de su familia.  Dentro de los  cultivos que más sobresalen en la zona es: maíz, papas.   Vende los productos en la ciudad de Guaranda cada cosecha.
Nancy solicita el crédito para comprar ureas, abonos, semillas y fertilizantes.  Su meta es  mejorar sus terrenos ya que esto le generará mayores ingresos económicos.   Los desafíos que enfrentan son que en tiempo de cosechas los precios se ponen muy bajos o existe riesgo de perder la producción. Nancy manifiesta que ayuda en sus momentos libres a su madre en quehaceres del hogar  y cuando no hay mucho trabajo sale a pasear en San Miguel.
texts.en:
Nancy is 19 years old, single, and does not have any children. She lives in the neighborhood of San Francisco de Rumí Pamba, an hour and a half from Cantón San Miguel in Bolivar province. Nancy is a member of the rural loan group "San Francisco de Rumi Pamba", which is composed of 25 members in total, of whom the majority are farmers. Nancy has worked in agriculture all her life, and this is the primary source of income for her family. Among the most outstanding crops of her area are: corn and potatoes. Every harvest time, she sells her produce in the city of Guaranda. Nancy is requesting a loan to buy urea soil additive, fertilizers, and seeds. Her goal is to improve her land so that it will bring her greater income. One of the challenges that she faces is that at harvest time the price of produce is very low. There is also a risk of loosing her crop. Nancy says that in her free time she helps her mother with the household chores and when there isn't much work to do she goes out for a stroll in San Miguel.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Urea soil additives, fertilizer, and seeds

loans.name: The United Brothers Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “United Brothers” group. They are small-scale businessmen in Waterloo, a small town, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. They have applied for a loan of SLL 4,000,000 for the entire group from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living standards will improve.
 
Steven M. (left) is the leader of this group. Steven was born in Bo, a city in southern Sierra Leone. He is thirty-three years of age, married with no children. Steven sells spare parts for both motorbikes and vehicles. He has been selling spare parts for twelve years now. With his share of the loan (SLL 1,500,000) he will buy general spare parts to add to his shop inventory.

loans.use: Buy spare parts to add to his shop inventory

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Abass is a 36-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has two children. Since 2008, he has been working as a car cleaner. Abass has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase a cleaning machine for his work. This is the first time that he has requested a loan. His clients can be anyone. 

When Abass first started his business, he was lucky not to face difficulties. He decided on opening his business because he realized that it was needed in his region, as well as because he wanted to improve his family's financial situation. He hopes to continue to improve his business, as well as be able to provide the best education and life to his children.

loans.use: To purchase a cleaning machine for his work

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: Z. Célestine est née en 1985 et vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Abokicodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Célestine est célibataire et n'a pas encore d'enfant. Célestine vit seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Célestine n'a pas fréquenté l'école, mais a appris la coiffure. C'est cette activité que Célestine exerce depuis près de dix ans, et qui lui procure des revenus l'aidant à subvenir à ses besoins. Parallèlement à cette activité, Célestine vend des mèches et des produits de coiffure dans son atelier. Célestine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi au Nigéria, pays limitrophe du Bénin. Célestine a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. La demande en produits cosmétique de la clientèle de Célestine se fait de plus en plus sentir et Célestine désire augmenter le stock de ses produits pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est donc pour y arriver que Célestine sollicite un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Z. Célestine was born in 1985 and has been living for about 10 years in the Abokicodji district in Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Célestine is single and doesn't have any children yet. She lives alone and supports herself. Célestine didn't go to school but instead learned hairdressing. This is the business that she has been in for almost 10 years and which brings in the income she lives off of. Alongside this business, she sells hair extensions and other hairdressing products in her salon. She buys her merchandise in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin, and also in Nigéria, a neighboring country of Bénin. Célestine has already received two loans which she correctly reimbursed to ALIDé. The demand for cosmetics among Célestine's clientele is growing, and Célestine would like to add to her stock of these products so that she can better satisfy her clientele. This is the reason why she is requesting a third loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hair extensions and other hairdressing products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new laptop

loans.name: Tessito Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité TESSITO est né au 5è cycle du Banc Villageois de GADAPARA en 2007. Il est composé de 09 femmes toute issues du même quartier. Elles se sont organisées par voisinage et par affinité.

Madame NGALA SONA S., debout à droite de la photo, est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 56 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants. 

Elle fait la vente de jus de fruits naturels. Des jus qu’elle fabrique de ses propres mains et qu’elle vend à domicile et au marché central du quartier.

Son prêt lui permettra de d’acheter des provisions pour la préparation de ses jus de fruits.

Elle cherche à travers les bénéfices qu’elle réalise à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Par le payement de la scolarité de ses enfants et la nourriture de la famille.
texts.en:
Solidarity group TESSITO was created in 2007, during the fifth cycle of the "Banc Villageois de GADAPARA". It is composed of nine women, all from the same neighborhood. They got together out of affinity and because they are neighbors. Mrs. NGALA SONA S., standing on the right in the picture, is the head of the group. She's 56 years old, married, and the mother of seven children. She sells natural fruit juices, that she makes herself. She sells them at her home and at the central market in her neighborhood. This loan will enable her to buy the ingredients she needs to prepare her fruit juices. With her profits, she wants to improve the standard of living of her family, by paying for food and for her children's school expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and ingredients to prepare fruit juices

loans.name: Alicia Teresa

texts.es:
Alicia F. es de la ciudad de Caaguazú, tiene 23 años y  está cursando el 5° año de la carrera de Ciencias Jurídicas y Escribania en la Universidad del Norte de la misma ciudad.
Ella tiene 1 hermana de 22 años quien es egresada de la carrera  de Contabilidad de la Misma Universidad al que asiste Alicia.
Su madre tiene un negocio de alquileres de mesas y sillas para eventos sociales y su padre es comerciante.
Alicia actualmente trabaja como Registradora en el Poder Judicial, donde se encuentra adquiriendo experiencia y al mismo tiempo obtiene un ingreso para sus estudios.
Ella tiene muchos deseos de terminar su carrera y abrir su propio estudio jurídico, crecer profesionalmente y ser destacada a nivel social por sus excelente labor como Abogada.
La clienta solicita el préstamo para el pago de la mensualidad de su facultad  ya que lleva dos carreras y tiene mucho costo.
texts.en:
Alicia F. is from the city of Caaguazú. She is 23 years old and in her fifth year studying Legal and Notary Sciences at Universidad del Norte in Caaguazú. Alicia has a 22 year old sister who graduated with a degree in Accounting from the same school. Her mother has a business renting out tables and chairs for social events, while her father works as a merchant.

Alicia currently works as a registrar at the courthouse, where she is gaining experience while earning an income to help pay for her studies. She is eager to finish her degree so that she can open her own law practice, grow professionally, and be recognized for her excellent work as a lawyer.

Alicia is requesting a loan to pay her monthly tuition. Since she is seeking to complete two degrees, the cost is quite expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for her monthly tuition

loans.name: Pedro Antonio

texts.es: El Sr. Pedro S. es originario del municipio de El Sauce, se desempeña como Inspector de sanidad para el Centro de Salud de dicho municipio donde tiene 28 años de laborar para dicha Institución tiene un año de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado dos créditos uno para mejora en su vivienda y el otro para gastos personales. El crédito lo solicitó para consumo con el fin de resolver necesidades en su hogar.
texts.en:
Pedro S. is a native of the municipality of El Sauce. He works as a health inspector for the Health Center of the municipality, the institution where he has been working for 28 years. He has worked with CEPRODEL for one year, where they have granted him two loans – one for housing improvements and the other for personal expenses. This loan that he has requested is for the purpose of paying for home needs.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Personal consumption

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita D. is married and lives in Jingjong Village, Brgy Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling fish. Her husband, Vicente D., is 49 years old and works as a baker. As time permits, he also helps his wife in her business. The couple has seven children who range in age from 7 to 24 years old.  Four of her children are already employed and helping out while the other three are still in school. Teresita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she wanted a better life for her family. With the help of eight previous loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she is succeeding in lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. She is applying for a new loan for PHP 11,000 which she intends to use to increase her income so that she can repair her house.

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To expand her small business so that she can afford to repair her house

loans.name: Yesenia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Yesenia, se dedica a la preparacion y venta de tamales, tiene 20 años de edad, vive con su esposo, su hija de 2 años de edad y su madre, todos realizan algun trabajo para aportar al hogar y cubrir sus gastos. El negocio de Yesenia inicio con la ayuda principalmente de su madre quien se dedicaba a vender tamales y le enseño a prepararlos, ella los vende el los alrededores de la zona donde sale todos los dias a ofrecerlos, no tiene un horario fijo pues depende de cuanto se tarde en venderlos.
Ella solicita un prestamo para la compra de Elotes que es su materia prima y los productos adicionales para la preparacion de los tamales, este prestamo ayudara a comprar los elotes por gran cantidad, que le den buen precio para que pueda ver mas ganancias en sus ventas.
Las aspiraciones de Yesenia con el negocio es que pueda mejorar su condicion de comerciante y pueda generar mas ingresos para ayudar a su familia y das a su hija un futuro diferente.
texts.en:
Yesenia’s activity is to prepare and sell tamales. She is 20 years old, lives with her 2-year-old daughter, her husband and her mother, who all have some activity to contribute towards household expenses.

Yesenia's business began essentially with her mother’s support who sold tamales and taught her how to prepare them. She sells in the surrounding area where she offers her products daily, without a set schedule as it depends on how much time it takes to sell off her production.

She requests a loan to buy corn -which is her basic ingredient- and additional products for the preparation of tamales. This loan will enable her to buy corn in large quantities, so that the wholesalers may give her a discount and she can in turn increase her sales profits.

Yesenia’s aspirations for her business is to improve her status as a merchant, generate more revenue to help her family and provide her daughter with a different future.

loans.use: Compra de Elotes para preparar tamales
